I think it would be just as good to compress the second half and keep the big final fight.

The first thought I had after finishing Harakiri was that I had just watched a Greek tragedy. Every aesthetic element of Harakiri from the empty scenery to the haunting soundtrack is stripped bare, sharpening the viewer's focus onto the human elements in Tsugumo's description of how his family was led to its fate by the hypocrisy of the Shogunate's hierarchy.The brilliance of the movie isn't in its relatively simplistic plot, but rather in the way it makes use of Tsugumo's framed story to detail the impact social codes have on those left behind by society's unfeeling march forward.As Tsugumo tells his story to an increasingly hostile audience, each scene serves to add further evidence to his point - which is the inherent cruelty in applying an unfeeling Samurai "honor" code to a messy reality. This goes on until the final act, in which he brilliantly exposes the tie between honor and the Samurai's most sacred symbols as a facade.In the final act, Tsugumo breaks the Imagawa Clan's self-righteous view of themselves with two actions. The first occurs in the final moments of his frame story, where he inverts the traditional relationship between a Samurai's sword and honor - turning Chijiwa's Bamboo sword, which was previously a symbol of dishonor into a symbol of familial loyalty/love. The second occurs after the Imagawa Clan rejects Tsugumo's message - as their leaders are shown to be dishonorable according to their own honor code and the clan's ancestral armor is desecrated during the final fight, which culminates in the Clan resorting to the use of firearms (over their sacred swords) to take down Tsugumo.But as mentioned earlier, society grinds on, and the now disgraced clan cover up both Tsugumo's tragedy and their own dishonor with the stroke of a pen. The question is - will the Clan heed Tsugumo's advice when the wheels of history inevitably turn them to Ronin?

While some so-called classics leave me cold, "Harakiri" (as it's known in the USA) really fires my imagination. This is a rare movie - the kind that I just can't stop recommending to people.Much of the film's appeal is based on surprising narrative twists, so I'm reluctant to delve too deeply into the plot here. But the basic setup is as follows - Japan has entered a time of peace, and consequently many samurai are unemployed and suffering in extreme poverty. Some samurai develop a ploy of threatening to commit suicide, but only so they can get sympathetic handouts of food and money from rich families. The film explores what happens when that ploy backfires in a very serious way.Director Masaki Kobayashi paces the film very slowly - by comparison, many Kurosawa and even Ozu films are breezy, and of course contemporary American films move approximately 800x faster. However, I am never really bored while watching "Harakiri"; the film slowly builds toward a (very rewarding) climax, while filling in the characters' compelling backstories. In short, this movie requires - but pays back - patience. Stick with it, and you'll be rewarded with interesting revelations and even some exciting (and surprisingly violent) fight scenes.Due to its unusual blend of action, emotion and social commentary, "Harakiri" has shot right up my list of favorite films. I'm tempted to describe it as a Tarantino-style film, only with more of a conscience and a sophisticated worldview. But I suppose that any such comparisons between "Harakiri" and American movies must be broad and a little crude. Kobayashi's film stands on its own, of course, and is well worth seeking out for any cinema fan.

It's truly one of the greatest examples of exploring humanism there is. Every character, even the protagonist, have their flaws that probably cost them a lot, but you're not left not understanding any character. You really can see the story from everyone's very different perspectives. It explores ideas that society never really stops to think about, like when is compassion more important than pride, or how literally should you really take things, and when do you really start abusing power. The concept of ritual suicide in the form of Harakiri, otherwise known as Seppuku, has captivated western imaginations for centuries. Indeed, the very notion of suicide, for religious or social reasons is viewed with a feeling of disdain within the western mindset. However, ritual suicide held an important ceremonial role for members of the Samurai class in ancient Japan. Viewed as an important component of the Samurai's Bushido warrior code, Harakiri was often used as a punishment but was often done voluntarily as well. It was a matter of honor and upheld the tradition of the warrior code. Harakiri forces the audience to confront the brutality of such a tradition and questions the morality of it. During the film, the main character questions both Bushido and the authenticity of the warrior code. He asserts that Bushido is a mere facade rather than a symbol of discipline. Whether or not these assertions are true, is a question that Harakiri leaves for the audience to decide.During the Edo period of the Tokugawa shogunate in Japan, it was common for master less samurai who were known as Ronin to request to commit harakiri in the palace of feudal lords.In this tradition, a man who goes by the name of Tsugumo Hanshirō requests to commit suicide at a powerful feudal lord's courtyard. Masaki Kobayashi directed this film to start out slow with the old man Hanshirō narrating a story. The story is about how the powerful clan at the courtyard was responsible for the death of Hanshirō's entire family. The old man confronts the powerful feudal clan in such a calm and authoritative manner that the audience is left at the edge of their seats. Hanshirō's daughter was married to a poor Samurai that was so destitute that he had to sell his blade to care for his family. He has a young baby who unfortunately gets sick and becomes desperately in need of medicine. When Hanshirō's son in law came to the Li clan seeking alms for medicine, they chose to punish him for disgracefully giving up his Samurai sword by forcing him to disembowel himself in the Seppuku fashion using the only sword he had left: a dull bamboo katana. After covering the dramatic backstory, the movie masterfully builds up to the final conclusion where Hanshirō uses every last ounce of his Samurai abilities to fight his way into the feudal lord's compound to desecrate his hall. The sheer force of will and determination displayed by Hanshirō's character on-screen is a testament to the acting abilities of Tatsuya Nakadai.Despite being shot in black and white, the film is aesthetically appealing as it depicts idyllic Japanese villages and sword fights in Samurai graveyards. At the climax of the film, the greatest line of the film is spoken. Before the culminating final sword battle, the main character proudly proclaims, "Motome had indeed gone mad. But I say good for him! I praise him for it. He may have been a samurai, but he was a man of flesh and blood. He could not live on air alone. When he has reached the point of no return, even a man as strong as Motome will go mad trying to protect his family, and I would praise him for it. They'll call him the bamboo ronin. Not only samurai, but townspeople, too, will scoff at his wavering. But let them laugh all they want. Who can fathom the depths of another man's heart?".

Essentially a condemning statement on the falsity of the samurai's supposed 'code of honour' and the concept of an 'honourable' death, this slow-burning drama sees a man recount his life as he prepares to take it in a ritualistic 'harakiri' ceremony. The tragedy of 'Harakiri (1962)' is profound and, as it moves from one phase to the next, it manages to emotionally affect in some surprising ways. It's a really layered piece, one with a multitude of intertwining themes and hard-won messages. The few sequences of violence it has are suitably brutal and exciting. They're grounded yet stylish, visceral yet thrilling, devastating yet inevitable. Arguably, the movie's most effective moment is an early example of its eponymous act, as a young man is forced to commit 'seppuku' in an incredibly cruel way. This scene is really difficult to sit through, to be honest, and it becomes even worse when the narrative revisits the reasoning behind its circumstances. The film is slow paced but it isn't boring. It's an interesting, entertaining but heavy affair. 7/10

"Another one? Is there no end?"So the clan elder of the House of Iyi greets the news that Hanshiro Tsugumo (Tatsuya Nakadai) is at his gate with an odd request.  Hanshiro, an old, impoverished, unemployed samurai, seeks use of their mansion to perform harakiri, ceremonial suicide that involves self-disembowlment and is an honorable death for a samurai living in disgrace.But in a time of peace, Japan abounds with ex-warriors who threaten to perform this rite only to extort money from weak-willed clans.  In light of such dishonorable conduct, the House of Iyi has adopted stern measures: Any samurai who threatens to perform this rite at their gate will be forced to do so.  Thus a younger ex-warrior, Motome Chigiiwa, met his fate.  Coming with the same request, this unfortunate youth was forced to carry out the rite with a bamboo sword -- "an unsightly affair."  The clan elder would warn the older Hanshiro away with the story of Motome's death, but the old warrior is resolved to die.Things, however, are not what they seem.  Hanshiro seems to have more on his mind than suicide.  And, as he relates his own lifestory to the warriors of Iyi clan, not only are their stern measures called into question, but also the very honor of which they are so proud.Seppuku is an awesome story of revenge told with devastating effect.  By the time you know what the story is really about, you yourself have cast judgement on the characters.  Then things turn on you, and nothing appears as it did before.  In this film a tragic story, great sword duels, haunting atmospheric music, and an exciting final battle combine to form what I think is an overlooked masterpiece.  Director Masaki Kobayashi does to the samurai genre what Sam Pekinpah will later do to the western in The Wild Bunch:  He takes the samurai code and turns it upon its head.  This film is great, and worth every repeated watching.

This film challenges all the elements of revenge, redefinition and ritual. A job very well done.

Masaki Kobayashi's "Harakiri" is a seminal masterpiece of Japanese cinema, a film that examines the complex relationship between honor, tradition, and power in feudal Japan. Released in 1962, the film remains a timeless and thought-provoking exploration of the human condition.At its core, "Harakiri" is a film about the futility of the cycle violence and the destructive power of revenge. The film's protagonist, Hanshiro Tsugumo, arrives at the doorstep of a powerful samurai clan, seeking permission to commit ritual suicide (harakiri) on their grounds. But as he tells the story of a former samurai who was forced to commit suicide under similar circumstances, it becomes clear that his request is more than just a simple act of honor, and this unravels into a heartbreaking, tragic tale.The film's exploration of the samurai code and the role of honor in Japanese society is both complex and nuanced. Through its portrayal of the rituals and customs surrounding harakiri, "Harakiri" examines the ways in which tradition can be used to justify violence and oppression.The script and dialogue of "Harakiri" are sharp and incisive, with each word carefully chosen to convey the complex emotions and motivations of the characters. The film's characters are richly drawn and fully realized, with each one possessing their own distinct personality and backstory. It is a character study of a man's raging, internal conflict, not an action-packed samurai flick like you might expect, but it is just as thrilling and even more provocative.The cinematography and directing of "Harakiri" are nothing short of masterful. The film's use of wide shots and close-ups is particularly effective in conveying the emotional and psychological states of the characters. The contrast between the opulent surroundings of the samurai clan and the desolate, poverty-stricken world outside serves as a powerful metaphor for the social and economic divides of feudal Japan.The acting in "Harakiri" is uniformly excellent, with each actor delivering a nuanced and powerful performance. Tatsuya Nakadai, in particular, delivers a standout performance as the film's protagonist, Hanshiro Tsugumo, bringing depth and complexity to a character struggling with the weight of tradition and the desire for revenge, which is a complex and tragic conflict. The rest of the cast also gives excellent performances as well, bringing depth to the characters and script. I particularly enjoyed Tetsuo Tamba's performance as well.The film is incredibly deep, it's themes provocative and powerful. For one, "Harakiri" can be seen as a critique of feudalism and the ways in which the ruling class uses tradition to justify their power and privilege. The contrast between the beautiful architecture of the Samurai Clan to the squalor and sheer misery of the peasants highlights this in Feudal Japan. Kobayashi also uses Feudal Japan to critique Post-WW2 Japan in a variety of ways, including how tradition can be used for violence and hatred, something incredibly relevant at this time. We see Tsugumo challenge tradition and the status quo in many ways throughout the film, which culminates in a bloody finale.Ultimately, "Harakiri" is a powerful and thought-provoking cinematic experience, a film that challenges the viewer to question their own beliefs about honor, tradition, and power. Its exploration of the samurai code and the rituals surrounding harakiri is both complex and nuanced, and its characters are richly drawn and fully realized. Masaki Kobayashi's masterful direction, combined with outstanding performances from the film's cast, make "Harakiri" a timeless masterpiece of Japanese cinema.

Harakiri (1962) is a Japanese film that takes place in 1630, and it is a story of the Samurai code of honor and family. Harakiri (also called seppuku) is the ritualistic suicide once employed by Samurai warriors to die while keeping their honor intact. A Samurai, Hanshiro Tsugumo, travels to the House of a rival clan Iyi, asking for a place to commit seppuku. Clans would permit such requests because it was an honorable final act for a Samurai to save his honor in their house. At that time, Samurai often arrived under a false pretense of committing seppuku but leaving with gold. The clan believes Tsugumo arrived under such false pretense. The story unravels from that point into a flashback of another Samurai, Motome Chijiiwa, who had arrived under such false pretense. I can't say anything more about the relationship between Tsugumo and Chijiiwa without spoiling the story.The filming style is interesting. It is depicted using dialogue and several flashbacks as it draws out the plot. The first hour is slow-paced, but the story picks up pace thereafter. It is ultimately a pushback on the Samurai code and the hypocrisy behind it.Would I recommend this? Yes, I believe it was very well done. The directing often reminded me of Akira Kurosawa's works. I would think the director of this film was inspired by Kurosawa. However, it's probably not for everyone because of the pacing, style, and lack of much action (until the last half hour). Not everyone likes subtitles either.

After a suicide pavilion is set up in the courtyard of the palace, the ronin is asked to name the samurai who shall behead him when the ritual is complete. Coincidentally, he has chose three samurai who have participated in the ritual of the unfortunate young ronin from the counselor's story. However, all three decline to come, saying they are suffering from a life-threatening illness. The ronin has laughed ironically and started his shocking confession...This is a very dramatic and tragic story with a very strong final climax. That ritualistic form of suicide is further reinforce the impression of a dark atmosphere. The main villain is a certain kind of a corrupt lord. A desperate and poor hero slowly serves his revenge, with the intent to humiliate and embarrass his opponents. An ancient tradition, political conflicts and shattered pride follow his painful confession. Mr. Kobayashi has enriched a tense situation with a vivid and sad retrospectives. The final battle is truly magnificent, even an occasional shred of theatricality has its role. Characterization is pretty good. Tatsuya Nakadai (Tsugumo Hanshirō) has offered an excellent performance as a desperate and poor, but focused and brave ronin.The brutality and an attack in the agony give us an entirely new expression of the ancient samurai world.

Masaki Kobayashi's Hara-Kiri is a great example of an all-around, expertly-crafted film. What is surprising is that this film is not as well-known as some of the other Japanese films from the golden age of Japanese cinema. Without a doubt, this film should stand high with the rest of them. The film seems to begin with a standard samurai story, but it soon branches off into a much more intricate and intriguing story dealing with love, suicide, dishonor, and revenge. One of the things that strikes me as particularly impressive about this film is the cinematography, which definitely seems ahead of its time. There is a lot of focus on the moving camera, and some of the shots flow so smoothly and capture the action in such artistically-stimulating ways that at times it is hard to believe this film was created in 1962. Some particularly modern shots are the ones during the opening credits where the camera dollies ever-so-slightly down tight hallways. The opening and closing to the film are of the same shot of samurai armor against a black background, and there is something artistically brilliant about this; beginning and ending a movie with the same shot seems to perfectly wrap things up and give a transcendental meaning to the content of the film contained between the two identical shots. In addition to the staging of the camera, the high-contrast blacks and whites make every shot in the film beautiful to look at.The story in Hara-Kiri is very emotional and can resonate even with modern-day Westerners that have little to no understanding of Samurai culture. One of the main themes, which revolves around the timelessness and importance of love and family, particularly had an effect on me, and drew me into the emotions of Hanshiro, the protagonist of the story. Overall, Hara-Kiri is a film that everyone should see. It is because of films like this that I have such an interest in filmmaking; there is no end to the inspiration that can come from such films that touch on the deepest questions of life and reach down into our innermost primal emotions.

"Harakiri", made by Masaki Kobayashi in 1962, is a tale of a former samurai, or ronin named Hanshiro's struggle to make sense of his son-in-laws unnecessary death, get revenge, all while essentially exploiting the corruption within the daimyo Iyi's manor. Kobayashi appeal to the audience is to reveal some truth behind and otherwise glorified samurai lifestyle. He tries to show the although a samurai's word is his bond and they follow a certain code, when that code or bond is broken for your own benefit, things typically collapse. This transforms to an system with a strict code governing its members, but is especially prevalent in the Japanese culture. Set during the Tokugawa Era, Kobayashi wants people to recognize that human life if much more important than any "Bushido Code" for samurais. Cinematographically, Kobayashi utilizes many black-and-whites, in a harsh landscape almost stylized like a painting. Emotionally, I really felt for Motome, Hanshiro, and his daughter and their struggle just to get by. Motome's fatal attempt to join the Iyi daimyo and his body's return to Hanshiro's are heart-wrenching moments that seem impossible to believe are actually carried out.

Just wanted to give my take on the film, and some of the reviews on the film.First if you haven't seen the film, simply put it's not just worth seeing, it's worth buying. It is a well performed, brilliantly photographed, hauntingly scored, and masterfully directed film.That said it's often spoken of in the same breath as SWORD OF DOOM, and that is highly misleading. If you go in expecting the visceral, brilliantly choreographed sword fights and unrelenting action of that film, you will not find it here.This is very much a drama, a morality tale of a time and a place; an exploration and an indictment of a way of life, and as such it has very few equals. The movie does lag, it is in many ways a monologue, one man talking more to himself than anyone else, of the ending of his life.But an enthralling story, captivating visuals, and above all else, one of the most intriguing and effective soundscapes since the great Dimitri Tiomkin's work on 1950s DOA, keeps this static film... moving and engrossing.Mentioning DOA, leads me to the bashing Hollywood takes regularly here from "critics" such as Landor28. Critics who in their rush to praise films, do it by backhanding other films. I'm not a critic, I'm just a reviewer. Critic implies you have some from the mountaintop perspective that gives you the right to criticize. Unless you've made movies, superior to what you're reviewing, you don't get to criticize. Review yes, criticize... no.Has Hollywood made bad films? Yes Hollywood makes its share of bad films, so does Japan, so does India, so does Hong Kong, so does every other country that makes movies. However Hollywood makes the most films, the most visible films, and the largest films, so it is an easy lump-sum target as opposed to taking each film on its own merits. Hollywood in fact is judged harsher by these critics, held to a higher standard than films from elsewhere in the world.I am no defender of Hollywood, as I don't work there, and not fortunate to know anyone who does, but I am a film fan, and a fan of the truth, and to praise films by Kurosawa and Kobayashi and to denigrate the films of Hollywood is to make a mistake these directors did not. These men, like all postwar filmmakers, were inspired by the films of Hollywood, particularly present in the work of all these directors is the large and brilliant work of John Ford.Kurosawa would be the first to state this. Fords widescreen westerns are at the heart of the cinematic recreation of the Samurai. The samurai world as envisioned by Kurosawa as much about history as it is the heroic imagery of the western. They are Stagecoach and Searchers transplanted to the east.A simplification to be sure, but not much of one. Postwar cinema in Japan and throughout the world copied from the states, and that's a good thing. And has started a trend that continues to this day of films successful in one country being copied in another. And we are the better for this two way copying. That's what film is people, copying.Copying a headline, or a book, or a play, or another film, copying a moment and making it your own. That's what all art is, looking at something, copying something, a sunset, a tree, a woman, a birds cry, and adding your own... bleeding to it. That's all life is, being influenced by something people have bled on, and if we are great men, leaving our own blood on it... to influence others.Only those with no art in their souls, don't see this. Only the very young, or the very stupid. Landor28 accuses Scorscese of stealing from Seppuku, an inane comment to make.How many shots in Seppuku but reecho earlier brilliant compositions of Stroheim. But I don't hear you calling Kobayashi a thief. And rightly so, no one owns a shot. Cinema, and images belongs to the story that can tell it. And if that image or look, can service well a thousand films, than it should be used a thousand times. What is film noir, but the same type of look, and camera angles used repeatedly. But used from the directors own viewpoint, it becomes the director's tale. So the comment of theft shows someone ignorant of the fact that there is nothing new under the sun, there are just 7 stories and 5 angles; and all cinema since.... but each person retelling this story through the lens of their own joy or pain.And if they are honest, the story each time... is worth hearing.Give these directors, whether they work in India, or New Zealand or Kenya or Hollywood their due. Shymalan is a great director, Weir is a great director, Fincher is a great director, Carl Frankin is a great director, Lee is a great director, Zimmerman is a great director, Gibson (for Braveheart not Passion), Ron Howard is a great director, Edward Zwick is a great Director (his resume since 89 reads like a bloody history lesson of great films.) and they all work in Hollywood, and their work inspires all kinds of foreign flicks you do rave about.Get off of Hollywood's back, it's always popular to hate the top dog, but it's also sometimes unwarranted.SEPPUKU is a great film, by a master director. ***1/2 out of ****. If you like it also check out these films: GLORY (1989 Ed Zwick), COURAGE UNDER FIRE, A HERO NEVER DIES, KING OF NEW YORK, LE SAMOURAI, SWORD OF DOOM, BACKDRAFT, Excalibur, TUAREG, MENACE II SOCIETY.They are all films about, to one degree or another, displaced honor and cannibal societies.

Now I may be biased about this movie over others due to the fact that I love watching Japanese cinema, but Harakiri was a well crafted and brilliantly well thought out movie made by Masaki Kobayashi. All the actors and actresses acted well on their individual roles. I enjoyed watching and learning the ways of the Samurai Culture. The Samurai Culture was all about obedience, honor and respect. Most Japanese films these days also try to make their movies more vague and make their audience question the characters actions and story plot lines. However, this movie is straight forward and to the point. I really like this film and the way it was constructed. It gave me more insight of the life of the samurai. Even though it doesn't come close to my favorites Japanese movies such as Departures, Battle Royale, Spirited Away or Confessions, it does the subject of Harakiri justice where it fully explains the way of the samurai code well.

My favourite Kobayashi, and among my favourite Japanese films of all time, "Harakiri" (known in Japan as "Seppuku"; the former is a spoken term, the latter a written one for the same thing, the former likely adopted in the West on the basis of some general awareness of the word) is a masterly exploration of space, symmetry, honour, disloyalty, tradition, modernity and truth.This film has one of the most amazing opening sequences ever. It goes beyond the best of Greenaway or Tarkovsky in how the camera moves and reveals a space, and I'd like to know whether Zhang Yimou considers this an influence on the similarly masterly "Raise the Red Lantern" (Da hong deng long gao gao gua, 1991). Especially the framing in the exterior shots is just as beautifully conveyed. Anyway, back to the sequence – there we are introduced to the idea of the "house": not only in the sense of "assembly" but also as a building. The main visual motif of the film (the courtyard scenes are another) is very theatrically revealed in shadow and light, and even before the narrative begins (we enter a book read to us, which again, appropriately, is not the whole truth).I am so in love with how the film looks and how the camera moves. Symmetries open, are revealed, tighten. There are amazingly patient tracking shots, especially in the interiors, where the camera sometimes barely moves at all.The performances are just as amazing as the rest of the craft. In fact, this film brings together two absolute icons. For me, Tatsuya Nakadai is the quintessential Japanese actor, even greater than Mifune. His presence is overwhelming, just as his humanity. His eyes speak more than a thousand words in mere glances. Rentarô Mikuni is another, and his work in Ichikawa's "The Burmese Harp" (Biruma no tategoto, 1956) and in Imamura's films (most notably in "The Profound Desires of the Gods" [1968] and "Vengeance is Mine" [1979]) adds tremendously to my viewing experience. There are two very good Blu-ray editions available for this, released by the Criterion Collection (Region A) and the Masters of Cinema series (Region B). The Criterion appears to be cropped on the sides to a surprisingly noticeable degree, however.

I had the belief that "Harakiri" was going to be a boring Japanese movie. Masaki Kobayshi the director shut me up completely. By the time I finished watching this film I was stunned by how good it actually was and had me thinking that I shouldn't judge a book by it's cover. Although it's good the film does gets boring, mainly in the beginning then it has a roller-coaster of emotions, then the final showdown just leaves you stunned. The film itself is a masterpiece in Japanese cinema as this is the film that put Japan on the cinema map and laid the foundation for many other masterpieces from Japan. I would recommend this film to viewers who like samurai type films.

Kobayashi is one of the unsung heroes of Japanese cinema. Ozu and Kurosawa get all the ink, and they do so undeservedly to my mind. Kobayashi, Shinoda, and Mizoguchi do get respect, but their skill and artistry should elevate them above Kurosawa if not Ozu as well. Harakiri is, probably, my favorite samurai film, which, I think, derives from its willingness to talk and explore the concept of the samurai and the code of honor by which they abide. Harakiri seems, to me, to work on a number of levels, while most of Kurosawa's films operate on the most basic one. Rashomon digs deeper, but the rest seem content to exist as fun little action movies with great vistas. Harakiri is different. The setting also helps. The compound in which the action takes place is one of the most amazing sets I've encountered in any film. It seems magical to me, and the cinematography of the interiors is astounding. Like most people, I'm usually more struck by gorgeous photography of open land; interiors are harder to film in interesting ways. Harakiri manages to make the inside of the compound spare and, occasionally, unreal. It's magnificent. Overall, I think this film is immensely enjoyable and will appeal to anyone with an appreciation of Japanese cinema--especially those that would typically avoid a samurai movie.

This is a very ambiguous movie. One commits seppuku whether his lord asks him to or he commits it because of the loss of faith. This story is about a ronin, basically an unemployed samurai. The protagonist in "Harakiri", Hanshiro, portrayed by Tatsuya Makadai, is the only one in the whole movie who actually follows the samurai code, and at the end he is killed by it. Violence takes place in the film as well, so make sure you are mentally prepared to watch people disemboweling themselves with bamboo swords. I enjoyed the emotional cut of the movie and instant shots which really reflect characters' despair and happy flashbacks from their past. Interesting choices were made by the director, Masaki Kobayashi, who has always been interested in the anti-establishment of the world, samurai culture in particular. Everything becomes really tragic when Hanshiro's friend performs seppuku, or when his daughter and grandson die Meanwhile, Hanshiro blindly follows the samurai's code and falls into dogmatism. He assumes seppuku is something true and follows the rules no matter what. Some scenes may seem funny for a contemporary viewer; Kobayashi was trying to add a little humor. Tragedy, politics, drama, and comedy The film has it all. I would recommend watching this film to those who are stricken by Japanese samurai movies.

A stumbling block for a Westerner is that we are dealing with the Japanese world of the 1600's where Samurai were once the enforcers but were then no longer needed and cast aside. They became beggars and men without hope. There was no work for them. Some then turned to a the realities of the Samurai code. This was Harakiri, which is the ritual disemboweling of the self with a sword in front of a group of clan members. Making things more complicated is that some of those leaders stepped in and provided charity for these men, leading to a wave of them seeking money. But in this one, a young man whose real story we don't know till the end, presents himself for self execution and then wants to go away for a while. He is kept there and eventually, using a bamboo sword, takes his life. But the big story is a man, connected to this young man, who also presents himself, and he tells a tale that is so sad. While this take a great deal of commitment to watch, don't miss it. Outstanding.

What can be defined a good movie? The movie Harakiri can be the great example. This is a movie with a serious theme means through this old, black and white movie, people can get to know the Japanese samurai history in the specific time period(1619-1630). This movie also can be considered as a historic documentary.According to the plot, it was pretty simple— a déclassé samurai whose daughter and grandchild were sick, the son in law had to go to Kageyu Saito's house to beg for some money by choosing harakiri in front of Saito's house. But Saito did not want to know the reason that forced son in law seppuku by using a bamboo katana. Then the samurai fought back, criticized ruthless rulers and exposed their hypocrisy. In the end, the matter was covered up by the authority, and no one knows. In Masaki Kobayashi's movie "Harakiri", it contained two strictly parallel corresponding stories. From the structure, these two stories were divided into serval parts, and were orderly placed into the plot according to the rhythm and the progress of the story in order to create a rigorous form so that the movie would have a significant theatrical feature.For people, it is natural to love, to be loved, and to survive. Masaki Kobayashi's "Harakiri" or "Seppuku" is filled with drama and suspense. Kobayashi decided to tell the story in a non-linear style with plenty of flashbacks. This allowed the viewer to remain on edge, filled with skepticism and anticipation throughout the film. This director has no limits. I don't think I have ever had such a reaction to blood and gore in a film as I did in Harakiri. It got me to my feet. I completely respect his decision to show those elements, as they were completely necessary. This choice commanded that the viewer recognize from the very beginning that this was not just a story of life and death but a tale with deeper meaning. Isolationism was the overall theme of this movie, and Kobayashi does a spectacular job of sticking to this. Whenever we see Hanshiro telling his story from the courtyard we are overwhelmed with this sense of isolation, an every man for himself type of feeling.Cinematically speaking, the choices made in this arena felt ironically inviting and apprehensive simultaneously. Kobayashi makes the choice to shoot the majority of the film at kneeling height or eye level, because that is where the majority of people remained throughout the entire film. It is really one of those films that leaves you questioning, which makes sense as the director was prominently known for questioning all things Japanese.

There is a law in human society. No matter what, if it exists for a long time, it will slowly deteriorate, decay, and rigid. As soon as the heyday of the Taiping arrived, there was no need to fight anymore, and Bushido gradually became empty furnishings and forms. Young warriors have hardly ever seen war, and warriors have only become a symbol of identity and status. Like the armor of the ancestor worshipped on the altar, it will not be used for a long time, and it has lost its original meaning and has become a meaningless worship. Bushido, like feudal autocracy, is rigid, degenerate, and decaying. The big name is to maintain the dignity of Bushido, in fact, to maintain the identity and pomp of his nobility.
The film illustrates the decline and deterioration of this Bushido from three different directions.
To the beggar, he was a young warrior, and he also lacked a deep understanding of these tedious warrior temperaments and spirits. However, he is also a simple man, a law-abiding person. However, in the face of the burden of the family, he had to let go of this spiritual pursuit, facing the cruel reality, and sold his sabre with pain. A man who has abandoned all dignity for his wife and children is miserable and bears humiliation. For him, Bushido is just a spiritual obsession, a distant cold spiritual pursuit. He couldn't reach it, so, like a deadly law, he was finally abandoned in the presence of a warm and tangible family. However, the most tragic thing is that this man who was deprived of his dignity and spirit was ultimately killed in his injustice.

I really enjoyed this Film. You definitely need to know the historical background of Ancient Japan to understand the film. It takes place in a time where thousand of Samurai where out of work and thrown into poverty. It was very interesting to see another cultures perspective on honor and loyalty. I felt bad for the ronins that where poor and had no way to survive. Harakiri is a ritualistic suicide for Samurai in Ancient Japan. This is an honorable ritual. The film tends to jumps around in different points of view throughout the storyline, so make sure you pay attention. What I took away from this movie is that sometimes the traditional ways of respecting authority must be questioned, especially when it comes down to what you believe to be right or wrong.

The director's use of light and lens is so wonderful that the sense of form and story fit perfectly. After reading it, I was speechless for a long time: the reality is cruel and the ending is ironic. It's not so much that bushido spirit is disappearing, but that it can survive after being replaced with a funny appearance.

Mizoguchi does an excellent job at creating a strong willed character that will stop at nothing to expose dogmatic followings of the Bushido code as unnecessary and unethical. I admire Mizoguchi for going against his cultures beliefs in order to showcase his own for others. So often we are quieted by what our religion, parents, culture, etc. expect of us; we are never able to claim our own identity and beliefs in fear of rejection. Hanshiro, who is against the dogmatic version of the Bushido code, is ironically the one samurai who embodies the noble side of it above anyone else. I feel here Mizoguchi was trying to deliver the message that following your own beliefs and "orders" is far more valuable than following others orders. Anyone can be a dogmatic follower only a few can think freely and passionately enough to be a counterforce to wrong acts that are seen as societal norms. You can definitely feel that Mizoguchi was influenced by the French New way in terms of how he decides to tell the story—it's not particularly in chronological order. Instead it is a story that is told through a past story (Motome's experience). By telling both of these stories you can further understand what fueled Hanshiro to be the admirable rebel that he is.
A real samurai masterpiece, perfect. The hypocrisy and cruelty of Bushido and the oppression of human nature, the small people against the times and the magnificent tragedy of the system.

Soldier Masaki Kobayashi directed the Jedi-geki piece "Harakiri", which is about a man who is on the quest of committing sepuku (suicide), a respectable death in an honorable place for respectable Samurais. The movie starts out slow with the dialog, because the pace of the scenes and the actors are soothing on a monotone level (I understand that with the Samurais in a sacred place, that is part of their mannerism and culture). However, the more you watch the film, the pace starts to pick up as you listen to the story play on by (there are a series of flashbacks implemented into the scene). As you progress into the film, it turns out that the Samurai is looking for an honorable death, but he is also there to mock the code of the Bushido, and the unbalance that exists within the system that cost him his son in law's life in a horrid way, who he cared for as a son.Kobayashi takes us on a journey about how man, in a corrupted system, tends to either dehumanize us into walking robots, or giving us a choice to find balance in society. I though this was brilliant of him to put this film together, especially since he was a soldier himself, and got persecuted for similar parallel circumstances (not the suicide, but the system of "doing your job" in a military stance). Tatsuya Nakadai (who played Samurai Hanshiro Tsugumo) did a brilliant job and stole the show. There is a spiritual element in the film, but I suggest to watch the film and pay attention to the dialog, because this film will really make you think about our current society today.

A veteran samurai arrives at a feudal lord's home to commit an honorable suicide ritual. Things take an unexpected turn when he starts telling his reasons to commit this act. I know the director Masaki Kobayashi from his The Human Condition trilogy, which is in my opinion the greatest movie trilogy of all time, with parts 1 and 3 being one of the greatest movies of all time. So naturally, I was really excited to see Harakiri, the movie many people call his magnum opus, and I can say now that is definitely for a very good reason. This movie was absolutely outstanding. First of all, I really loved the pacing of the story, and how it revealed information in a very suspenseful way, that created this amazing buildup towards the end of the movie. On a personal level, this story is very harrowing. There are many scenes in this movie that I would consider to be some of the most heartbreaking and painful scenes I've ever seen. These moments are highlighted with fantastic acting, especially by Tatsuya Nakadai, whose performance in The Human Condition is one of my all-time favorites, and his performance in this movie is also definitely up there. The movie also deals with themes like honor, especially in the historical context of the Japanese samurai code, and criticizes this authoritarian culture within the samurai clans, in a very thought-provoking and interesting way. I really liked the use of music in this movie, which is very minimalistic. The black and white cinematography was outstanding. Especially framing and camera movement were excellent. Harakiri is of the greatest masterpieces in cinema history, and Masaki Kobayashi blew me away once again. I haven't seen most of his filmography yet but I can already say he is one of the greatest movie directors of all time for me.
